questions.question_text: Which of the following should be an information security manager's PRIMARY focus when migrating data between two dissimilar systems?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
this safeguards the data’s confidentiality, integrity, and compliance with relevant regulations

choices.B: Ensuring the integrity of system backups
choices.D: Determining the amount of effort required
choices.A: Developing automation to facilitate the migration

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
it provides robust security against unauthorized access and interception. 

Confidentiality = Encryption

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the BEST way to protect the confidentiality of the information returned by a new application programming interface (API) integration?

choices.D: Use only APIs with de-identified data.
choices.A: Require all API requests to be monitored.
choices.C: Ensure all API traffic is encrypted in transit.
choices.B: Update the privacy policy to include use of the API.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is MOST likely to be considered confidential data as opposed to personal information'?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Customer income level is most likely considered confidential data, while the other options fall under personal information due to their direct link to identifiable individuals

This seems to be tricky question. Answer is C. 
Here's why:
Confidential Data vs. Personal Information:
Confidential data often refers to sensitive information that must be protected from unauthorized access, which can include proprietary business information, trade secrets, and certain technical information.
Personal information, on the other hand, typically relates to identifiable information about an individual, such as their name, identification numbers, or demographic details. 
Other options are all considered personal information.

If you look at the zones in the data lake, it is ordered in the following fashion as temporal, raw, trusted, and clean. The moment data enters the raw zone, it should be protected using encryption or tokenisation. Hence, C is the correct answer.

comments.content:
To support this view see this:
Transient Zone — Used to hold ephemeral data, such as temporary copies, streaming spools, or other short-lived data before being ingested. Raw Zone – The zone in which raw data will be maintained. This is also the zone where sensitive data must be encrypted, tokenized, or otherwise secured.
https://dzone.com/articles/data-lake-governance-best-practices#:~:text=Transient%20Zone%20%E2%80%94%20Used%20to%20hold%20ephemeral%20data%2C,data%20must%20be%20encrypted%2C%20tokenized%2C%20or%20otherwise%20secured.

Sensitive data should be encrypted or tokenized in the Trusted zone of a data lake. The Trusted zone is the area where trusted data is stored, and access controls are tightly managed. It is typically used for highly sensitive or regulated data, such as personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, and health records. The other zones within a data lake, such as the Clean zone, Raw zone, and Temporal zone, may also contain sensitive data, but they are typically less secure and do not require the same level of encryption or tokenization as the Trusted zone.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The answer provided is incorrect. Sensitive data should be encrypted or tokenized in the raw zone, not the temporal zone. The temporal zone is for ephemeral data.

questions.question_text: Which of the following zones within a data lake requires sensitive data to be encrypted or tokenized?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Rounding and nulling are examples of masking, as they modify or obscure data to protect sensitive information while maintaining partial utility

questions.question_text: Rounding and nulling are examples of which type of data de-identification function?
